title: FBI hunts for 'Asia's El Chapo' who runs drug empire worth $17billion a year
text:

FBI authorities are on the hunt for a mysterious drug trafficker dubbed "Asia's El Chapo".

A multinational task force is trying to track down Tse Chi Lop, a Canadian national born in China who is suspected of leading a vast drug network that accumulates up to $17 (£13) billion a year.

The syndicate provides tonnes of methamphetamine, heroin and ketamine to at least a dozen countries in the Asia-Pacific region, from Japan to New Zealand, authorities believe.

Meth, a powerful drug that can create very strong psychological and physical dependence, is believed to be the network's main business.

Tse, who is protected by a guard of Thai kickboxers, flies by private jet and once lost $66 (£52) million in a single night at a Macau casino, police say.

His narcotics empire was allegedly born out of an alliance of five of Asia's triad groups.

Police have dubbed the network Sam Gor, Cantonese for "Brother Number Three", which recalls one of Tse's nicknames, but its members simply call it "The Company".

In 2018, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) estimated the syndicate's revenue at $8 (£6) billion a year, but says it could be as high as $17.7 billion.

(Image: VIA REUTERS)

The agency estimates that the cartel, which often conceals its drugs in packets of tea, has a 40 percent to 70 percent share of the wholesale regional meth market that has expanded at least fourfold in the past five years, according to a Reuters investigation .

A Taiwanese law enforcement flow chart believes Tse is the “Multinational CEO” of the syndicate, but police have not publicly identified him as the suspected boss of the trafficking group.

Jeremy Douglas, Southeast Asia and Pacific representative for UNODC, said: “Tse Chi Lop is in the league of El Chapo or maybe Pablo Escobar.

“The word kingpin often gets thrown around, but there is no doubt it applies here.”

Sam Gor supplies a bigger, more dispersed drug market and collaborates with a more diverse range of local crime groups than the Latin cartels do, including Japan’s Yakuza, Australia's biker gangs and ethnic Chinese gangs across Southeast Asia, Reuters reports.

“The crime groups in Southeast Asia and the Far East operate with seamless efficiency,” one veteran Western anti-drugs official said.

“They function like a global corporation.”

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

Tse Chi Lop in Guangdong Province, in southern China, and grew up during China’s Cultural Revolution.

In 1998, he was taken to court on drug-trafficking charges in the Eastern District Court of New York.

He was found guilty of conspiracy to import heroin in the US, court records show.

He was facing a potential life sentence but told the judge a story about his ailing parents and sick son, after which he was sentenced to nine years in prison.

Police suspect Tse, who was freed in 2006, quickly returned to the drug trade, but the true scale of his syndicate only became apparent in 2016, when a young Taiwanese man entered Yangon airport with a bag of white powder strapped to each of his thighs, Reuters says.

The authorities involved have so far refused to comment on the investigation.

Mexican drug trafficker Joaquin Guzman Loera, commonly known as "El Chapo", was the leader of the Sinaloa Cartel, a criminal organisation named after the Mexican Pacific coast.

In February this year, he was jailed for life after being found guilty of trafficking cocaine, heroin and marijuana and engaging in murder conspiracies.
description: Tse Chi Lop is suspected of leading a syndicate that provides drugs to at least a dozen countries in the Asia-Pacific region
